projects.title: Prayers for Computer Science
projects.description: A collection of prayers for Computer Science students and professors

children.title: The first day of a new semester (students)
The first day of a new semester (professors)
Beginning a new course you've never taken/taught before
The start of a senior capstone project
The beginning of a sabbatical for research
The week before spring break (exhaustion setting in)
During a particularly challenging unit or module
The last class meeting of a course
Graduation day (for professors watching students leave)
Choosing a major in computer science
Switching into CS from another field
Declaring a CS minor or concentration
Moving from undergraduate to graduate study

toc.title: I. The Rhythms of the Academic Year

children.title: Before reading a particularly dense textbook chapter
Starting a problem set that looks impossible
When everyone else seems to understand but you
Encountering proofs for the first time
Making sense of lambda calculus or functional programming
The first time your code compiles and runs correctly
Solving a problem you thought was beyond you
Making an unexpected connection between concepts
Understanding why something you memorized actually works
Opening your laptop to work on an assignment
Starting office hours visit (when you need help)
Before asking a question in class
Reading documentation or Stack Overflow for help
During an exam (when stuck or panicking)
Waiting for grades to be posted
Before a code review or presentation

toc.title: II. The Work of Learning (For Students)

children.title: Updating course materials for a new semester
Learning new material to teach it
Before class begins (those few minutes alone)
When you realize students aren't following
Answering a question you don't know the answer to
Teaching the same material for the 20th time
Demonstrating live coding (and hoping it works)
The last few minutes of class
During a difficult conversation with a struggling student
When a student comes seeking career advice
When you must address academic dishonesty
Before grading a large stack of assignments
While grading (when your eyes grow weary)
Writing feedback that is both honest and encouraging
When you must assign a failing grade
When research hits a dead end

toc.title: III. The Work of Teaching (For Professors)

children.title: During a group project (when conflict arises)
Contributing to open source for the first time
When your teammate isn't pulling their weight
When you're not pulling your weight
When a colleague leaves or retires
At a CS conference or symposium
At Grace Hopper or similar conference
When your research community feels competitive rather than collegial
When the mentoring relationship is difficult
Saying goodbye to a graduating advisee
Writing the first line of code
Choosing a tech stack or architecture
When the creative flow is strong
When you've been debugging for hours
When you find the bug (relief and sheepishness)
When tests fail (discovering what you missed)
Maintaining code years after writing it
When you wonder if you chose the wrong field
Missing important personal events for deadlines
Making a costly mistake in production
Discovering your code will be used unethically
Pressure to cut corners or compromise
When you must report academic dishonesty
When asked to build something you believe is wrong
Designing systems that affect vulnerable populations
When you realize CS is/isn't your calling
Considering how your skills serve others
When you must decide: money or meaning?
When humbled by what you don't know
Using version control (Git) for the first time
Lost work (before learning to commit often)
Returning to a problem with fresh eyes
Arriving at the lab or office
Closing your laptop for the day
When a student is struggling personally
Watching a student discover their calling
When you must be firm but loving
When a student opens up about mental health
When a professor shows extraordinary care
When you disappoint a professor you respect
Learning to see professors as human
When non-CS people don't understand your work
Trying to explain what you do
The mystery of consciousness and AI

children.title: When a pioneer in CS passes away
Remembering key moments in CS history
